intro: Phuphanochloa, commonly known as the golden spikegrass, is a genus of flowering plants belonging to the grass family, Poaceae. It is native to tropical and subtropical regions of Asia, particularly in countries like Thailand and Cambodia. The plants are characterized by their tall, slender stems and dense, golden-colored inflorescences that resemble spikes. Phuphanochloa species typically thrive in moist, well-drained soils and are often found in wetlands or along riverbanks. These grasses play a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various insects and small animals.
